Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Investigating the impact of hybridization on diversification: A case study in the plant genus Heuchera
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hybridization is broadly relevant because it is the basis for much of the diversity around us, including agricultural crops and pests. The existence of successful ancient natural hybrids between species challenges traditional notions in biology that hybrids are ephemeral dead-ends in the evolution of biodiversity. However, detecting ancient hybrids using genetic data is challenging since hybrids have a "mosaic" of genes possessing different underlying histories and traits.

In this project, the investigators will test hypotheses about ancient hybridizations, specifically whether Pleistocene glaciations have enabled hybridization by causing range shifts. The proposed work will be conducted within the genus Heuchera by comparing species richness between hybrid and parental lineages in several parallel cases that have been identified. This project analyzes Coral Bells (Heuchera) from a DNA and morphological perspective to investigate the long-term contribution of hybridization to evolution. The objectives of this study include (1) the discovery of hybrids, (2) examination of relative rates of species formation with parents, and (3) reconstruction of historical geographical ranges. This study contributes to scientific infrastructure through the provision of DNA sequences for comparative studies, data for the inference of evolutionary history, descriptions of new and rare species and varieties, and the creation of museum specimens and identification keys. The project includes training of undergraduates in research methods, the creation of pedagogical exercises for undergraduate classes, and public lectures on hybridization in general and on specific aspects of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hybridization, the crossing of individuals from different species, has increasingly been recognized by scientists as a potential process behind the origin of some species. Yet scientists still debate the relative importance of this process since it seems to contradict a common and ancient definition of species as reproductive communities, taking the example of the sterile mule, which might not be representative of all organisms. Recent work has increasingly identified hybrids, and our work has bulit upon this by identifying ancient lineages of plants whose ancestor originated with a hybridization event. Identifying derivatives of ancient hybrid organisms is important because these are living pieces of evidence that hybrids can withstand the test of time and behave as other lineages of organisms -- that they are not evolutionary dead-ends -- splitting into new species that diverge in their physical traits and ecology.

We used the plant genus Heuchera (coral bells, alum roots; common garden plants in temperate regions) as our study system because hybridization among the species is thought to be common in nature and is certainly common in the garden. The particular type of hybridization that is thought to occur in Heuchera involves the complete transfer of the genome of the chloroplast (the organelle of the cell that is responsible for photosynthesis). If hybridization occurs by this pathway, DNA sampled from the chloroplast genome should have a different history from the nuclear genome (tracing the history of the donor of the foreign genome). We sampled nearly all of the species and sequenced a fairly large portion of the genome (400,000 base pairs) to examine these alternative histories.

First, our work produced the first well-supported (nucleus-based) tree of life for Heuchera. We also produced a tree reconstructing the history of the chloroplast genome, which was even more divergent than what had been reported previously. We used this nucleus-based tree to test the likelihood of obtaining relationships in the chloroplast tree under a statistical model that does not include hybridization. This simulation indicated that our chloroplast tree was extremely unlikely without hybridization, indicating a role for this process in the evolution of the group. Comparison of chloroplast and nuclear trees revealed that some of these hybridization-mediated transfers involved ancestral species, validating the idea that hybrids are not necessarily temporary phenomena.

Secondly, our work has resulted in a new strategy for DNA sequence data collection. For groups that originated very recently in geological times, researchers find obtaining suitable DNA variation to be a perpetual challenge. Yet often the least variable portions of the genome have been sequenced for technical reasons. We have found that directly aiming for more variable portions of the genome can be quite successful.

In the future, we will continue to use these data (and we would underline the continuing and often unanticipated importance of evolutionary trees to diverse researchers). Our hybrid detection work identified instances where hybridization may have occured, but the contributing species are not currently in the same geographic region. We hypothesize that this could be caused either by divergence in the ecology of the organisms since the time of hybridization, or by past climate change (such as occurred during the ice age) causing geographical range shifts that enable organisms to exchange genes.
